J.B.,

I was just getting ready to respond and tell you that you're full of
fluff then I though of checking the latest version. I have version
1.0.0. It looks like version 1.0.1 has the elusive exactly() method. I
just downloaded my version so this new change must have happened in
the past week or so. Oh well. It's late now and I have to go get my
daughter from day care. I'll pick up on this tomorrow. Thanx J.B.!

Cliff
BTW:
I was toying with the after() and onConsecutiveCalls() stuff and I
started getting some interesting but inconsistent results. I'll write
back tomorrow.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> cliftonccraig wrote:
> 
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> >  > Yes. Since it's just a stub, it's set up simply to return your
value.
> >  >
> > That's what I thought.
> > 
> >  > Invoke verify() at the end of the your test /and/ set the
> > expectation to
> >  > "at least five calls" and not "at least once", as you're doing
now. (I
> >  > don't know the precise syntax.)
> >  >
> > 
> > That's what I need. I need the precise syntax to enforce a given
> > number of invocations. There is no atLeastNumTimes() method that I can
> > find to enforce this. I only see once() and atleastOnce() methods.
> >  > So change what you pass to expects(), then be sure to invoke
> > verify() at
> >  > the end of the test.
> > 
> > Interestingly I haven't had the need to invoke verify at the end of my
> > tests. I know it's good practice but it appears as though JMock gives
> > immediate verification.
> 
> It does, but only if something unexpected happens, and not if the 
> something expected doesn't happen. So the 6th invocation fails fast,
but 
> not the missing 5th.
> 
>  > Anyhows, what I really need is a good example
> > of how to setup an expectation for a given number of invocations on a
> > single method. I also want to incorporate different return values for
> > each invocation. In essence what I'm mocking is a custom interator.
> > Could someone give me a good how-to on this?
> 
> Let's see...
> 
> It looks like you can use exactly().
> 
> blah.expect(exactly(5))....
> 
> Have you tried that yet?
> -- 
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
> Let's write software that people understand
